et: International Scientific Vocabulary, from Greek {it}meros{/it} part {ma}{mat|merit:1|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}any of several English-based pidgins spoken on islands of the western Pacific

et: French, alteration of {it}biche de mer{/it}, from Portuguese {it}bicho do mar{/it}, literally, sea worm
shortdef: any of several English-based pidgins spoken on islands of the western Pacific

dt: {bc}any of several large sea cucumbers (as of the genera {it}Actinopyga{/it} and {it}Holothuria{/it}) that are taken mostly in the southwestern Pacific and are boiled, dried, and used especially in Asian cuisine

et: borrowed from Indonesian Malay {it}teripang{/it} (phonetically {it}təripaŋ{/it}), probably borrowed from the second element of Indonesian Bajau (Austronesian language of Sulawesi and other islands of eastern Indonesia) {it}balaq talipang,{/it} name for the holothurian {it}Thelenota ananas,{/it} literally, {ldquo}centipede sea cucumber,{rdquo} from {it}balaq{/it} {ldquo}sea cucumber{rdquo} + {it}talipang{/it} {ldquo}centipede{rdquo}

See Akamine Jun, {ldquo}Trepang and Lalipan: A Linguistic Note towards the Reconstruction of Social History of Maritime Southeast Asia,{rdquo} {it}Hakusan jinruigaku/Hakusan Review of Anthropology,{/it} vol. 13 (March, 2010), pp. 35-41. Akamine does not specify whether the form {it}talipang{/it} originates from his own fieldwork or from a published (or unpublished) source. Assuming the form exists, its plausibility as a source for Malay {it}tǝripaŋ{/it} would be high. For the many and divergent outcomes of proto-Malayo-Polynesian {it}*Ɂaluhipan{/it} {ldquo}centipede,{rdquo} see Robert Blust, {it}Austronesian Comparative Dictionary{/it} (on line). The earlier English form {it}tripam{/it} was borrowed from French (as in {it}L'Histoire philosophique et politique des établissements et du commerce des Européens dans les deux Indes,{/it} tome premier, La Haye, 1774, compiled by Guillaume-Thomas Raynal). The immediate source of the French form is not certain.
shortdef: any of several large sea cucumbers (as of the genera Actinopyga and Holothuria) that are taken mostly in the southwestern Pacific and are boiled, dried, and used especially in Asian cuisine —called also bêche-de-mer
